action.action-desc: Mr. Marino introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on House Administration, and in addition to the Committee on Rules, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 to prohibit the use of public funds for the payment of a settlement or award under such Act in connection with a claim arising from sexual harassment committed by a Member of Congress, and for other purposes.

section.header: Prohibiting use of public funds for payment of settlements and awards under Congressional Accountability Act in sexual harassment claims involving Members of Congress

subsection.text: Section 415 of the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 (2 U.S.C. 1415) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a), by striking subsection (c) and inserting subsections (c) and (d); and
by adding at the end the following new subsection:

subsection.header: No use of public funds for payments of awards and settlements in connection with acts of sexual harassment committed by Members of Congress
subsection.text: No funds of the Treasury of the United States may be used for the payment of an award or settlement under this Act in connection with a violation of section 201(a)(1) if the violation consists of an act of sexual harassment committed personally by a Member of the House of Representatives (including a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to the Congress) or a Senator.
The amendment made by subsection (a) shall apply with respect to settlements and awards paid on or after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Mandatory consideration by ethics committees of expulsion of Members of Congress committing acts of sexual harassment under Congressional Accountability Act

subsection.header: Mandatory consideration of question of expulsion
subsection.text: Title V of the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 (2 U.S.C. 1431 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating section 509 as section 510; and
by inserting after section 508 the following new section:

section.header: Mandatory consideration by ethics committees of question of expulsion of Members of Congress committing acts of sexual harassment
section.text: If it is determined in any final decision entered under section 405(g) or 406(e), or in any decision in a civil action brought under section 408, that a violation of section 201(a)(1) occurred which consisted of an act of sexual harassment committed personally by a Member of the House of Representatives (including a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to the Congress) or a Senator, or if the payment of an award or settlement under this Act is ordered in connection with a violation of section 201(a)(1) which consists of such an act—

paragraph.text: in the case of an act committed by a Member of the House, the Committee on Ethics of the House of Representatives shall conduct an investigation and issue a report on the question of whether the Member should be expelled from the House; or

in the case of an act committed by a Senator, the Select Committee on Ethics of the Senate shall conduct an investigation and issue a report on the question of whether the Senator should be expelled from the Senate.

subsection.text: The table of contents of such Act is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating the item relating to section 509 as relating to section 510; and
by inserting after the item relating to section 508 the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 509. Mandatory consideration by ethics committees of question of expulsion of Members of Congress committing acts of sexual harassment.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to acts occurring before, on, or after the date of the enactment of this Act.
